review_title: Great place to work, but career progression is difficult
pros:
Leader in the industry; highly intelligent employees; well thought out processes
Mature structure and thinking 
Generally collaborative - not hierarchical
cons:
Career progression is very difficult - even for employees with consistently high ratings. Must move to a different company in order to get a promotion.
Generally, people managers are not focused on managing people - only a few show excellence in this regard. (Not that different industry wide)
There is some bureaucracy that was starting to slow things down more than was necessary to mitigate risk
Less competitive in salaries/benefits than realized until leaving
Advice to Management
Assessments are needed when high performers in certain areas are leaving often.

pros: Good place to work. Great Team. Good drugs.
cons:
Upper management is clueless. Drugs are hard for prescribers to use due to reimbursement issues. We are selling specialty drugs to primary care offices and most of them are not equipped to manage these types of drugs. And we are only allowed to help so much.
Advice to Management
Lower the price and keep it stable for longer. You’ll make it up in volume. Or you can keep things as they are and you will continue to lose business to 340B hospitals and truly make less money. Give non 340B hospitals discounts the same as a physician’s practice so they can at least break even.

review_title: Amgen needs to be brave and create opportunities for emerging Scientists
pros: Solid company and benefits. Good moral compass and eye for social/societal issues. Good picture science. On a granular mid-management level, there are challenges.
cons:
After a while, growth prospects get thin and you are forced to carve/force a path for growth - due to the sensitivities of others. Some departmental functions do not allow enough opportunities for Scientific growth, specifically in leadership spaces for younger emerging Scientists.
Advice to Management
Recognize and promote young talent. Year on year exceeds/far-exceeds = promote, no excuses. Don't get into arguments of appearance (age, how long it takes others to get promoted, perceptions based on sex/race). Don't worry about how an early but deserved promotion is perceived. Just do it. 

Also: Get non-innovative/high ranking Scientists out the way to create opportunity for those who currently driving the science.
Helpful (2)

review_title: Has so much potential to be a great place
pros:
The colleagues are generally smart, highly motivated and mission-driven
Good benefits
Solid balance sheet
Highly respected in the industry-lots to learn
Used to have lots of family friendly activities, but not sure what will happen to them after COVID
Management focused on the company stock price and market performance
cons:
-Work-life balance is non-existent. I am literally working all.the.time. Vacations are rarely taken. I have noticed that if my manager does not see me logged on and green on a weekend, the following week I get dumped a bunch of projects since apparently I have “capacity”. We have winter and summer shut downs but I have always worked through them so they are not that helpful
-There is a LOT of micromanaging - this may also be manager/department specific though. But from my experience micromanaging was very commonplace 
-Decision-making is slow and inefficient. This goes back to the several layers of micromanagement. 
-Career progression is tricky. Hard to know how you can really advance to the next level 
-I have had some bad, mean managers. It is disappointing that they think they can treat others in a derogatory manner and the company is allowing such an environment to prevail
Advice to Management
There are lots of talented people with good intentions. But the way things are and going, makes it hard for people to put in their best efforts. I really liked Amgen but I am not sure if I have the same belief in the company i had when I first joined. Have you not noticed that good people are leaving left and right???
Helpful
Amgen Response

review_title: True management is lacking, not a good sign
pros: Innovative, challenging work, great opportunity to learn and gain exposure.
cons:
Initially the work culture was fine. As time progressed, the culture became toxic. The individuals that were often times downplaying others, overly political, insecure were getting promoted over those with integrity. True management was lacking. This type of behavior caused many of the most qualified, hardworking, friendly, and enthusiastic team members to leave.
Advice to Management
When you promote individuals who are unprofessional with heavy amounts of unconscious bias, you will see the creativity, motivation, and productivity of your overall team decrease. Treating individuals poorly doesn't go unnoticed by the team, and eventually this will create distrust within the organization. 

My advice is pay attention to the political climate. Confront these issues head on before they trickle down and affect the overall organization.
Helpful

pros:
People are generally nice, approachable, and collaborative; and the compensation and benefits are both good and fairly competitive (pay, healthcare, retirement, childcare, campus / facilities, etc.).

The mission statement of the company is really strong and the products Amgen makes do really change people's lives. It's nice to be a part of that and to hear their stories.
cons:
It's a big, established pharmaceuticals company that is mostly concerned with preserving its market share / cash flow, and that is how the business approaches just about everything. The business tends to sequester and under utilize talent and IP, so innovation and career growth is slow compared to other companies in the industry.

There's also a culture of micromanagement, where leaders tend to not trust their teams and struggle to delegate anything of importance. From what I've seen, this is fairly consistent across departments and up/down the management chain.
Advice to Management
Focus on developing and empowering talent. Train leaders to be leaders rather than micromanagers.

pros: Company has a respectful culture among employees where individuals are treated professionally and enabled for success with great onboarding training. Contributions are recognized and high quality talent is hired. Policies and practices support a strategic focus. Beautiful campus with great amenities, favorable time off policy, competitive compensation and other benefits.
cons:
Company tends to cycle through phases of hiring and layoffs. Leadership sometimes desires strategic input with insufficient time to collect and prepare the information. Usually not the case, but can be stressful when it occurs. Also, culture can be somewhat bureaucratic making it difficult to get to know employees in other groups and at other levels.
Advice to Management
Try to allow sufficient time for preparation of strategic materials by staff members, and try to promote better level of interactions between groups and different levels of employees to work on some of the silo effect that exists. However, overall it is a great company with solid leadership and good culture and the department enables success.

review_title: Great place to build a solid foundation in GMP manufacturing process
pros:
- High salary 
- Good Benefits and two weeks of paid holiday shutdown / year
- 401 K 5% contribution and up to 5% matching 
- High pace and dynamic manufacturing environment which exposes you to multiple different bio processing processes
- Wide range of work and floor operations so everyday is different 
- Helps develop essential business skills
cons:
- Very unprofessional on the floor - major favoritism by FLMs / shift leads
- Major divide between shifts which do not encourage team work and effective collaboration
- Extremely long hour shifts with limited breaks(1 hour lunch break) 
- Stressful work environment outside of the job requirements (mostly politics)
- Strong push back from management and no support for internal lateral or vertical career moves
- Lots of work and limited staff - high call off rates
Advice to Management
Provide more effective training and guidance to FLM team as they have a strong impact on their reports. Managers should uphold and exemplify the Amgen standards. Manufacturing FLMs should maintain professionalism and work on developing the strengths of their direct reports and department team as a whole. High turn around rate due to a lack in the above mentioned basic requirements that management team should have. Remember that manufacturing positions are entry level jobs that provide the company with a great understanding of the potential of early career individuals. In order to hang on to high potential and performing staff management team should really focus on developing and shaping these individuals to further contribute to the Amgen mission as a whole.
Helpful

pros: 1) 401(k). 2) Thousand Oaks is a nice area with great weather. 3) Many colleagues (especially those at Director level or lower) are highly science- and evidence-oriented. 4) Many well-meaning colleagues
cons:
1) Management by process rather than reason and inspiration. This company is led by its lawyers and Microsoft Excel. 2) Upper management that's generally out of touch with what's happening on the ground. 3) Management that prefers to punch and delegate down than take responsibility. 4) Some upper management with toxic attitudes who, despite complaints, are never disciplined. However, don't you dare be anything but perfectly professional if you're not an ED or higher. 5) Leadership that says one thing and does another. For example, the top-down push for "aggressive prioritization" is juxtaposed by assignment of MORE low priority work and MORE metrics/processes. 6) Development that moves along at a snail's pace despite everyone being overworked due to metrics/processes. 7) A Stalinist corporate environment where people are afraid to speak up. 8) (Department-specific) Lack of appreciation for the people doing the real work on the front lines. 9) (Department-specific) Poor overall compensation by industry standards. 10) An inordinate amount of time updating timelines and budgets for management review. 11) Poor work-life balance; you will be hard-pressed to use your vacation time due to the sheer amount of work and fire drills. Everyone is assigned to multiple programs but expected to be 100% on all of them, another indication that the drive for prioritization is nothing more than empty rhetoric. 12) A deluge of FAKE reviews on Glassdoor via third-party astroturfers to combat downward trajectory in rating. These end up burying the legitimate reviews. Not out of the ordinary, but Amgen is one of the few companies that has hired a PR company to combat negative perceptions on Glassdoor. That should tell you something.
Advice to Management
Listen to your employees instead of treating them like a number. The fact that Amgen's stock has performed well due to aggressive, unsustainable cost-cutting does not make the company one that's worthy of respect, nor does it afford it the means to attract and retain top talent. Act on your promises, stop shirking your responsibilities, and work on figuring out ways to improve systemic problems that have plagued the company for the past decade. There are large companies that do it better with fewer resources at their disposal; strive to emulate them.
Helpful (9)

review_title: It’s a pleasure to be out of this limbo!
pros: The only positive is the team members you will have the pleasure to work alongside. I do believe Amgen has some of the most talented people in their respective fields, but they also have a hard time keeping the smart ones. Those that stay have a callousness quality, which is fed back into the culture negatively.
cons:
Expect to work 12 hours a day or more on the average if you are in any position of responsibility.

a) The organization lacks structure, and support is rarely available to guide the team when it counts. 
b) Management will often de-rail projects within the group by getting involved in the weeds without remediating any of the problems. 
c)Expect to be micromanaged, and if you happen to have any new ideas, the old guard is there to tell you all the reasons why it can’t be done.
d) Management is too busy managing up and does not have time to coach novice team members. I think this is a serious issue that needs to be addressed. 
e) There are at countless hours of team meetings that are often disorganized and waste time. 
f) None of the management knows how to facilitate professional usability studies nor moderate a session. 

That is just the tip of the ice iceberg. If you are looking for a place to grow your skills, this is not the place. The real decision-makers are outside consultants 100% of the time. 

It's mostly project management (Project Management 1.5). They are mainly involved in managing usability studies. Most of the work is designing labeling and IFUs (user manuals). The product lineup is also dull if you are interested in a complex system; this is not the place.

Finally, it is essential to note the nature of the device development is not driven by the free market where the best product and design need to be made to compete. They are not in the business of selling devices but drugs. This leads to mediocre products to meet the minimum. Its a shame with all the money they spend.

I can go on and on, take it from me and find another opportunity!
Advice to Management
Focus on growing all employees that are willing to put in 100%, not just the ones that naturally shine. There a lot of talent and sad to see young people not getting the guidance they should to grow.
Helpful (4)
Amgen Response
December 9, 2020 – Social Media Manager

It is our sincere goal to foster an environment where staff members can thrive professionally and personally, and reviews are instrumental in our ability to implement change. These are specialty positions with seasoned, successful reps...do not hire reps that require you to micromanage. Seasoned, successful reps want yo sell, not push around numbers on spreadsheets for hours each week when Amgen already pays for people to do this...not the est use of time.

pros: Some strong and friendly people. Great benefits.
cons:
Didn't feel empowered to escalate a culture issue within the organization - felt powerless to do anything except leave.
Advice to Management
Consider the indicators of the health of an organization and act decisively. Many people left my organization and it grew more and more toxic. I literally could not do my job as my decision maker dodged responsibilities, while throwing me and my team under the bus. I did not feel empowered to escalate this issue as he and his boss were close. Although Amgen tells employees that they can seek help for these kinds of issues, believing that sentiment when you are no longer objective is difficult.

I don't hold this against Amgen as a company, I just want them to be aware of the health of their organizations. I truly believe Amgen wants to do right by their patients and community responsibilities. I just feel that this is a bit of a blind spot.

review_title: Best Place I Have Ever Worked - But let’s work on promotions
pros: Amgen offers everything you could possibly want out of a company. There is immense room for growth, so many different& interesting areas to get involved in outside of your role, an amazing culture, excellent benefits and work life balance (including winter and summer shutdowns, 3 weeks Vacation on top of that, 2 weeks sick time, even volunteer hours... 401k you get 15% for contributing only 5% of your salary and restricted stock units granted every year on top of your bonus). The work we do is truly saving lives... I especially appreciate how Amgen re-focuses our perspective regularly and will bring in patients to tell their personal stories. I am so grateful for this experience.
cons:
Some individuals tend to value doctorate degrees over real, scientific experience. They also look down upon engineers... It’s really a bummer for the culture. Promotions are also pretty slow... causing us to lose top talent to other companies.
Advice to Management
Consider implementing a program for faster promotions - We have been losing a lot of talent in the Cambridge area for this reason alone. Slow promotions at Amgen = Double Promotion at a new company. We need to retain our talent!

review_title: Yikes - Wasn't Expecting Such a Horrible Experience!
pros:
1. Benefits - Amgen offers incredible benefits, which is probably why the majority of individuals stay there for so many years.
2. Financial Stability - They are higher on the salary dependent on your industry.
3. Beautiful Campus - a gorgeous location with a lot of outdoor seating.
cons:
**This is a reflection of my experience of my role and might not be reflected in other departments**

1. Leadership and Management are horrible! Needs a lot of improvement. Whoever hired senior management needs to double-check who they've hired. They hired individuals who are not well-versed when it comes to effectively building strategy or leading a team. 
2. Meetings, Meetings, Meetings: Expect to constantly be in meetings. The running joke is that you have a meeting to discuss scheduling another meeting.
3. They promise work-life balance, but there is none. I worked every weekend for the 3 months that I was there. 
4. It's a constant game of hot potato. Tasks keep being handed off to other individuals and there's no accountability. 
5. Horrible work culture: There is no company-wide events, no bonding, everyone is VERY siloed. 
6. Lots of drama and toxic work environment - a lot of people love to gossip!
7. Narrow-minded - maybe it was just my department; however, they had a very conservative outlook.
Advice to Management
Train your leaders to actually know how to manage! You go through an extensive sexual harassment training, yet the environment is still toxic. Some senior management might have had years of experience, but they do not know how to lead a team! Hire individuals who actually know how to create a strategy, and follow through with building an effective game plan instead of pawning it off to someone else.
Helpful (9)
Amgen Response

pros:
People - I had the privilege of working with not only intelligent people, but also people who care about their impact on the world
Benefits - The benefits program did change and was reduced a bit, it was still one of the best packages available at any company I've worked for
Patients - It's not often that you get to work at a place that has real purpose and when you know that you are contributing to saving and improving lives, there is almost nothing better
Diversity - Amgen has always had an incredibly diverse workforce at all levels even before it was popular
cons:
Career Opportunities Limited - opportunities for career advancement were a bit challenging if one did not want to be a biologist, scientist or technology specialist. It prevented me from being able to explore certain areas any further than where I was, when I left. 
Dependent on Credentials - from a hiring perspective, the prevalent management culture focused disproportionately on degrees and certifications. While those are important there were a number of highly qualified people that were passed over as a result.
Advice to Management
You have generally been committed to diversity at all levels and it shows in hiring and promotions. However, given how good Amgen is traditionally, it might be appropriate to expand the notion of diversity to be more inclusive beyond gender and race. One examples is for recruitment and hiring of non-college degree or certificate only employees and applicants. When I was there I saw a couple of very qualified individuals that were not considered for a position because of they lacked the specific education, but their experience and ability to problem solve was exceptional. Sadly, those people went to other companies and we lost out on their experiences and perspective. Insight and innovation can come from a multitude of places and when diversity is only about race or gender, it limits the ability for new ideas to develop.

review_title: Still Working out the Kinks at Amgen Tampa
pros:
*Awesome 401K Match
*Good Co-workers
*Lots of opportunities to get training you can take somewhere else
cons:
*No RSUs for lower level, day to day employees
*You have to wait a Year+a quarter for ESOP
*No Privacy - to the point they police you if you take a shared space for too long.
*Very Poor career development from Directors and Managers
*Constant cost cuttings - The four stars I am giving for Comp and Benefits is for the Benefits alone.
*No systems training
Advice to Management
*Start listening and participating with the lower level employees you are expecting to do the jobs. 
*Stop repeating the same things over and over (process flavor of the week), what worked in California, may not work in Florida. 
*Stop saying everything is Number 1 priority.
*If you are going to keep hiring people without the exact skills but have potential, put some money into developing the skills training to do the job.
* Reassess who you have managing, there are very few leaders.

review_title: The good, the bad, the ugly
pros: Amgen is situated in Thousand Oaks outside of Los Angeles in a very family oriented area. It is surrounded by nature and offers ample opportunity to go hiking in the hills. Lots of nature nearby. But also is at high risk when the wildfires start, like just recently. Many Amgen employees were evacuated from their homes - the fires were that close. The benefits are excellent - vacation and 401k contribution are among the best in the industry and make leaving difficult - there are not many alternatives in the area and , considering some of the cons, the golden handcuffs keep retention rates artificially high. Compensation and bonus, however, have experienced a down trend.
cons:
Not all is well in MedAffairs. I'm hearing about Directors whose cruelty forced employees into leave of absence and others who are entirely out of touch with what's really going on. I'm hearing US MedCom Onc is ridden with a overly biased, managerial anti talent who's been propagated way too long after having experienced a complete turnover of their previous team. Instead of leading a the team to excel with enthusiasm, the turnover has already begun. 

The Amgen performance ratings system is failing its employees. Sub-par ratings need to be filled with quotas whether people deserve it or not. The exact same rating system is currently under fire at Facebook and, as some may know, has been discontinued for good by Mircosoft in 2003 for being a disaster.
Advice to Management
1) It is known (by observation and based on an email to all-staff by no other than Bob) that women make up more than half of the workforce. This is the result of years of systematic hiring and development of females over males. Amgen is not an equal opportunity employer - likely due to attempted overcompensation of other employers shortcoming but entirely misguided. I'm all for equal opportunities for both genders - fix this unfairness and get yourselves back to save grounds legally....
2) Get rid of the inhumane performance ratings system and managers who derive pleasure from dishing out criticism.
Helpful (8

review_title: Not a good place to work.
pros: Good benefits package. Good profit sharing plan.
cons:
When asked of HR in an open forum, "Does the company value work/life balance?", the HR person had to pause (not a good sign) and finally said, "Yes, but sometimes you have to fight for it." In my experience, that's overly optimistic. They treat everyone like wide-eyed military recruits that they can just keep heaping demands upon.

Management is at best inept. Who plans to replace the entire AR/AP system 30 days before the close of the fiscal year, when 90% of the workforce has less than 90 days on the job? That's just dumb. (It was a disaster)

Lots of good people left because of the reorg/move to Tampa, and the folks remaining in California were resentful (perhaps with good reason). They have showed little respect for the new folks in Tampa that they had to train.

The CEO touts the "open concept" workspace layout as saving up to 25% on overall real estate costs, which I'm sure it does. It's ironic that a company in the health care space creates an office environment that is sterile - no plants, no pictures, no privacy.
Advice to Management
Stop using the mantra, "we're here to serve our patients", as a blunt instrument to browbeat employees.
Helpful (24
advice_to_mgmt: Stop using the mantra, "we're here to serve our patients", as a blunt instrument to browbeat employees.

pros:
You'll never be bored! Really smart, hardworking, and genuinely good people here. Resources are there (if you're in the right department) and there's a strong focus on safety and improving/automating repetitive tasks. It seems like there's a lot of room for growth if you're talented and ambitious.

I've also found management to be receptive to new ideas. But the most important thing to keep in mind is that every department at Amgen has a completely different culture and feel. Find a job you can excel at and a group/manager you can work well with and you'll thrive here. The former is as important as the latter here.
cons:
Amgen is a company constantly in flux. It seems like there's a re-org every year or two. This has it's pro's and con's but it's often the case that things change before they are fully functional and this is constant.

From what I've gathered from many full-time employees Amgen will put you through a ringer to get a raise and promotions are hard won and are years in the making. This combined with a very lean work force has lead to a lot of attrition lately.

Amgen also loves to hire contract workers. It seems like half the work force is temp. The agencies they use tend to take a lot off the top and disparity in wages for the same job can be quite bad. These agencies also generally have minimal benefits and will lie to you to take a bigger cut of your pie. You really have to be ambitious, network, and often have to move departments to break out of a contract position.
Advice to Management
It often feels like there's a disconnect between what upper management decides to do and what seems the obvious solution on the ground or that deadlines are arbitrary. Communicating reasoning and the data behind it would help teams execute with greater confidence and direction.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: It often feels like there's a disconnect between what upper management decides to do and what seems the obvious solution on the ground or that deadlines are arbitrary. Communicating reasoning and the data behind it would help teams execute with greater confidence and direction.

pros: Intelligent, Driven, and Tenacious Staff.
cons:
Retaliate for Whistleblowing, Gross Misuse of Resources, Ego driven impulse decision making with no quantifiable value, Back door politics, likability favored over Skill and Integrity, HR Managers Can ask you if "You want to take it outside" and not get fired, Fact Based Analysis Will Get You laid Off, Excessive Wasteful Spending On Neat Gadgets and Gamer Desktops, Outdated or non-existent documentation, Identifying Gaps In the Change Control Process Will Get You Laid Off, Task Lists and Success criteria are infinite moving targets, Will actively prevent future employment or derail opportunities with other employers, Will Watch and Listen from your laptop while remote or working from home in your bedroom.
Advice to Management
Get Some Leadership Training, Listen to Your SME's Not Your EGO, Police Your Own, Most importantly JJDIDTIEBUCKLE:

Justice – Being fair and consistent. Giving consideration for all sides of each decision, and having rewards and punishments based on merit.

Judgement – The Ability to think things through in a clear, and orderly fashion so as to make the right decision.

Dependability – Having the ability to be relied upon to perform duties properly, and complete a job. Always putting in best effort so as to achieve the highest standards of performance.

Initiative – Taking action even if direct orders haven’t been given and using resourcefulness to solve problems.

Decisiveness – The ability to make good decisions calmly and quickly, and announcing your decisions in a clear, direct and professional manner.

Tact – To deal with people in a manner that will maintain good relations and avoid problems. It means that you are polite, calm, and firm.

Integrity -To be honest and truthful in everything you say and do, and value sound moral principles above all else.

Enthusiasm – Performing of your duties with excitement, optimism, and willing to accept the challenges

Bearing – The way you conduct and carry yourself. Manner should reflect alertness, competence, confidence, and control.

Unselfishness – To be considerate of others, giving credit to those who deserve it. To make self uncomfortable at the gain of others.

Courage – To remain calm, even while recognizing fear. Having the strength to stand up for what is right. Functioning effectively when in immediate physical danger.

Knowledge – An understanding of science, art, and people. Knowing your job, the unit’s policies, and being informed on current events.

Loyalty – The devotion to country, and the Marine Corps. Unwavering loyalty up and down the chain of command, to seniors, subordinates, and peers. The motto of the Marine Corps is Semper Fidelis (Semper Fi), meaning “Always Faithful”.

Endurance – Mental and Physical stamina, which is measured by your ability to withstand pain, fatigue, stress, and hardship.

review_title: Good Benefits and Competitive Pay - Zero Leadership
pros: Beautiful campus and one week shut downs in winte / summer. Pay is competitive.
cons:
Health benefits have gotten terrible. Management is ill equipped and untrained. Continuous "improvement" initiatives that take years to develop and are extremely poorly implemented. Complete lack of training and increasingly unclear direction are common themes. Two additional weeks of time off, is not work the lack of support and development opportunities at this company. Things have continued to decline and I imagine they will not improve any time soon or at all given the condition of the current company state.
Advice to Management
Train your managers. Especially those who are new to being a manager and or lack past management experience. Management is often absent and disconnected from their reports, but still allowed to give reviews based on less than a handful of interactions throughout the year. There is no option to rebuttal comments or concerns within a review, setting you up for potential detriments to your career based on reviews with managers you seldom worked with.

pros: Good benefits, but these have diminished now as earnings decrease
cons:
Staff are not empowered or encouraged, limited development opportunities, moral and treatment of staff that have been employed for over 10 years is poor. As a manager I was told what ratings to give my staff and had no say in the matter. I was told to give some of my staff poor reviews to save the company money rather than accurately accounting for their success. Large exodus of talent and experienced staff will likely cause critical compliance issues to arise soon.
Advice to Management
For departments with great losses of talent where those left are just relentlessly taking on work allow for the possibility for no one to get a partially meets or poor performance rating. Grading on a curve and forcing some staff to receive a poor ratings when they dont deserve it will cause more to leave and also severly lacks integrity. Also eliminate incentives for VPs to come in under budget for staff compensation. Encourage VPs who don't understand or follow Amgen values or encourage staff to understand or follow them to resign. If you mandate your VPs and EDs to treat staff with respect and integrity you might stop the exodus.

pros: Amgen has a great 401k plan (5% core + 5% match) and generous time off including 2 holiday shutdowns at 4th of July and Christmas as well as 2 weeks personal/sick time per year. Vacation time starts out at 3 weeks and goes up to 5 weeks by year 20. Vacation time can be rolled over up to a certain limit based on years of service. Personal/sick time is a use it or use it within a year and does not rollover to the next year.
cons:
The salaries appear to be lower when comparing to similar roles at other companies. The bonus and stock program used to make up for some of this but have reduced over the past few years and normalizing to target, which is 20% for Directors and 30% for Senior Directors. Merit increases are minimal and not on par with cost of living increases. Some years Director and above and other years Senior Directors and above have not gotten merit increase. There are limited career development paths including lateral movement especially for staff that are 45+ and have been there more than 12 years. The company has moved from being a nice biotech culture to a big pharma culture with more focus on the bottom line versus focus on people, science, and the products.
Advice to Management
Actively enforce Amgen values, which starts from the top by leading by example. Spend more time valuing employees with a lot of experience and their career development, which is severely lacking for the past few years. Amgen is losing great talent that they invested in only to let go of without any remorse. Need to adjust salaries given cost of living, to be on par with other companies since bonuses aren't as good as previous years to make up the difference and given the 15% corporate tax decrease from President Trump's plans, the company should pass some of this savings to the employees.

review_title: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times
pros: All the fringe benefits of a Fortune 500
cons:
Career Advancement relies heavily on direct manager feedback to quote "I would have to go to the annual promotion meeting and stand on the table and light my hair on fire to demand a raise for a staff member."
Advice to Management
Recognize and develop your key talent; more transparency on career advancement with tangible goals, timelines and less focus on a manager's singular opinion. The career advancement process and management accountability in place during my tenure was unfortunately very lacking. Twice departments I was in were given approval to hire a higher level employee (less educated and skilled for a fact) than myself instead of promoting a dedicated employee like myself from within and backfilling the lower position. It made no sense whatsoever and was highly disparaging from trusting any further advancement.

review_title: Good company that has major malfunctions in certain departments
pros: Good salary and benefits, great 401K, beautiful campus, intelligent coworkers
cons:
Way to much bureaucracy in senior management. Leaders of departments do not fight for their staff and result in management decisions that affect the work and work-life balance of the staff. Executives are almost completely out of touch with reality, setting up the "office of the future" environment and trying to show that they work in that environment along with all the staff when in reality, they set up a locked off section of the newest building where they are completely inaccessible. Leaders are arrogant and will only promote the staff willing to play the corporate BS. It's not the best or hardest working staff who are rewarded or promoted, it's the staff who know how to play the game. Changes to senior management occur far more regularly than the staff and when the changes occur, they bring in new processes which are then done for a couple of years and then changed again when someone else comes in. There are some Sr. Managers to Executive Directors who have survived the layoffs and been with the company for many years and many of these people are cancers to the company. They don't want to make changes to make work more efficient or allow the work-life balance to change. With the company layoffs always looming (almost every year for the past 10 years), most staff feel overworked, underutilized and unappreciated and are just exhausted from trying to meet the deadlines imposed by management who continues to ask for more from their staff with fewer people to get it done.
Advice to Management
Executives and senior leadership need to show that they care about staff and not require staff to produce "more with less." There should be a tradeoff of fewer deliverables or longer timelines in trade for loss of employees. Also, they need to get back to the original Amgen values of valuing employees. That is what made people work hard in the past and want to be part of Amgen. Now, the executives have it backwards thinking that people want to be at Amgen and take advantage of it by trying to work everyone to death.

review_title: Not so great anymore in IS/IT
pros:
Good benefits, time off, health and dental. Great 401k match. Flexible hours.
Overall, very nice and smart colleagues and scientists.
Good science and challenging projects from an IS perspective.
cons:
The opinions here pertain to the IT/IS organization and leadership at Amgen.

The IT/IS environment was great up to a certain point. That is, until the aggressive outsourcing (abroad, mainly India) of IT and IS duties started, with questionable quality of systems/applications support.

Lack of real dialog between some managers and their direct reports, questionable managerial attitude and practices in the IT/IS department lead by the Executive Director Arun Nayar.

Unreasonable assignments outside job description and misaligned with skill set and with workload.

The business practices listed here have led to significant attrition, loss of some great managers who really cared about their direct reports. And also led to work overload, stress and hostile work environment at times.

Mediocre base salary and bonuses.
Advice to Management
Value your employees, listen to them, promote real, meaningful, constructive dialog. Managers should be onsite, not on the other US coast, in order to promote real face to face dialog.

review_title: Good place, as long as you're not a contractor.
pros: Pay was good. Schedules are very flexible and the ability to work anywhere with your company supplied laptop is great. Cambridge location is in a great spot as long as you're taking the subway to work. I learned a great deal about the bio pharmaceutical industry and am now able to leverage a ton of MBA/business vocabulary I learned there. Amgen stock is a good one to hold right now because the company is all about profits over patients. The quality systems are good at shifting liabilities to vendors and holding them accountable.
cons:
As a contractor/contingent worker I was marginalized when compared to full time employees, it's part of the company culture. Every contractor is marked as such on all company communications (outlook/skype) so everyone knows who is and is not a contractor, for the purpose of identifying who should not be taken seriously. Amgen doesn't hire contractors in hopes they are good workers and wish to convert them as full time employees. Amgen uses contractors as temporary labor to get fast track or tedious projects completed and then they card discard them so quarterly profits look better. It is also a massively wasteful company when it comes to materials. This review would probably be better if I was hired on, but the group I was in was in the process of downsizing so there was no chance.
Advice to Management
Quit relying so much on contractors and get rid of the culture of divisiveness between full time employees and contractors. Remove the CW from job titles.
Helpful (6
advice_to_mgmt: Quit relying so much on contractors and get rid of the culture of divisiveness between full time employees and contractors. Remove the CW from job titles.

Much of the management structure is composed of people who fit the "Amgen culture," meaning they follow company group think, don't question authority, don't ask hard questions, and propagate a culture where meeting attendance is viewed as productive work and of the utmost importance.
Advice to Management
Remember a company is only as good as its people. It sounds so trite, so banal, yet ultimately is to true. Individual people are not interchangeable, and key skill sets don't grow on trees. Value the key people who bring difference and new ideas into the culture--don't shut them out because change is frightening.
Helpful (8

Value the key people who bring difference and new ideas into the culture--don't shut them out because change is frightening.

pros: Campus is amazing; 401k; good people who work hard
cons:
A crazy political game. Expectations are set beyond what is achievable for function. To move forward you need to show face in more than your day to day work load. Take on extra initiatives so that you become "visible" to all in the organization. Work isn't measured on your performance but rather how others perceive you. 
Company gives a message of empowerment and providing a culture of values however lacks to deliver on their word. Sr. Mgmt lies telling employees they are at the top of their pay grade when peers in same positions are making more and/or less. We all do talk to one another.
Advice to Management
Focus on people who do their job well. We don't need to be involved in socializing in order to prove our worth. Set clear expectations for advancement versus just checking off boxes to get to the next level. Be fair!

pros: I've been at Amgen for over 3 years. I've worked in 2 different business units and have had 4 different managers. Every mgr I've had has exemplified the Amgen values of putting the patient first and promoting a good work/life balance. My husband had a promotion within his company that would require a relocation. Amgen had an opening in that city and my current mgr reached out to the hiring mgr and totally supported me making the move. We ended up staying put but I can't tell you how much her support meant to me. Great culture!! Great pipeline!! 5 weeks of paid time off for new hires! Un-paralleled 401-K! Merit raise increases yearly. Personal/Sick days for you or if your child is sick. Great fleet car choices! I've had a Passat and now a Volvo XC-60. I hope to retire here!!
cons:
Seriously can't think of any.
Advice to Management
Continue to manage by the Amgen values and implement programs to increase employee satisfaction and ultimately retention. Mini-vans as a fleet choice would be awesome!

pros:
The people are wonderful. Everyone I have worked with is professional, knowledgeable, treats fellow employees and contractors with respect, values others' opinion and contributions, and works hard to achieve our common goal: deliver high quality medicines to patients. It really feels like this organization wants to help patients first and not just focus on the bottom line. It makes coming to work everyday a pleasure. 
The benefits are another advantage of Amgen. Employees are encouraged to (and actually do) completely log off during 2 week-long shutdowns. 
My boss is genuinely interested in my career development and we have regular conversations prompted by the company about achieving my goals.
cons:
Because of the nature of the business, there will always be times when overtime is required to achieve a deadline. Plus, management encourages accelerating timelines when reasonable without negatively affecting quality. However, in my experience, this is true of pharmaceutical companies in general.
The health insurance policy leaves a lot to be desired (high deductibles and copay), although I'm told it's standard for the industry.
Advice to Management
Keep focusing on the benefit we bring to patients and valuing your employees. This is why I am excited to be a part of Amgen.

review_title: Amgen - a magical place to work!
pros:
Great work environment! This is my second employment stint at Amgen. There is really no other place like Amgen. You will be surrounded by some of the most intelligent, hardworking, ethical, and nice co-workers that can be found. The company fosters great science, importance on a 360 view of decisions, and involvement of all. 
It also has a great environment outside of work. Whether you are interested in sports activity, hiking, cooking, or what ever . . . you will find others in the company that share that interest.
Living in Southern California is also a big plus!
cons:
The cost of living is high in SoCal. The compensation is competitive, but not over the top. The company, the environment, the people, the weather is why you should work for Amgen.
Advice to Management
Review compensation versus industry standards and adjust for cost of living in SoCal.

pros: Beautiful campus and great location (if you never plan to get another job), great pay and benefits (but they are being cut every year)
cons:
1) location: if you decide to leave Amgen, you are almost guaranteed to have to relocate for a new job as the TO location is isolated
2) Layoffs and Amgen's AFP program which is a fancy name for cost cutting and layoffs
3) Unqualified senior management: one does not rise to a leadership position because they have the right skills, background, education or talent, they are promoted because they play the politics game and "fall in line" Example: I am a licensed attorney who was reporting to someone that had a music degree and absolutely no experience in the subject matter.
Advice to Management
If you really want to streamline and cut costs, put qualified people in senior management roles who will challenge the status quo, hire external, if you keep promoting people with the wrong backgrounds who know nothing but the Amgen way, you will never learn of new ideas. Stop promoting those who fall in line and reward those who bring ideas and advice to the table even if it's not the Amgen way. Nothing hurts morale more than to see someone completely unqualified get promoted to Director or Executive Director roles solely because they can play politics and hide behind your excessive use of PowerPoint slides and create fancy, yet inaccurate, data.

cons:
Very political environment, competitive and back-stabbing, HR always sides with management. Doctors and psychologists in the area say that they have seen a significant increase over the years in the numbers of Amgen employees coming to them as patients needing treatment for job-related stress and depression.
Advice to Management
Study the old Amgen from 20+ years ago that was exciting, entrepreneurial, and highly team-oriented. Today's Amgen has lost its great past values and is now just a business focused more on the bottom line than on serving patients. Embrace the reality that Amgen is in a five-year corporate integrity agreement with the federal Office of the Inspector General for numerous grossly unethical business practices. Bring back the commitment to integrity. Replace the current slate of HR staff with new professionals dedicated to developing a company culture of integrity and respect for employees.

pros: Good 401K, great place to learn and start your career.

Agree with another review, Amgen used to be good, not anymore. The health insurance plan is worse and worse, premium goes up year by year, 2017 is a 38 dollars more / month compare to 2016. Amgen sent everyone a letter asking you to share more of their cost of the insurance plan---38 dollars more per month of whose salary is between 100,000 to 199,000. Even with this much premium, the deductible is 1500 dollars, without co-pay for anything, meaning you pay full with office visit. I visited doctor once this year,for something small, and paid 340 bucks in full. The insurance plan sucks now, but Amgen used to be good 5 years ago. With the new management team, new CEO, new CFO, Amgen cut off heavily in terms of employee benefits not only health insurance plan, for example, they cut off the expense on Xmas party, yes, you read it right, Amgen doesn't have a company wide Xmas party. 
Promotion here is another big issue, taking my department as an example, there is zero promotion to anyone in the past 10 years.

If the company wants to keep the talents, should stop cutting cost from the employee benefits.

Helpfu

pros: If there's one company value the company truly lived by, it's its value in work-life balance. European-style paid vacation right here in the US. That's just the start of an amazing and comprehensive benefits package. Absolutely the best employment I've ever experienced. I would give it a 5 star, but the experience was in the down trend in the latter 5 years (out of 14).
cons:
Continued focus on out-sourcing IT services and likely in all other areas. There use to be a sense that we strive for excellence in all areas of the company, but it's becoming more and more apparent profit margins has taken a much higher priority. Amgen is settling forpoor quality of service from these off-shore, out-sourcing entities and/or it's rushing to implement these services before they've thoroughly defined good processes. At any rate, in the latter years, you sense the company positioning itself in a way to that allows it commoditize its employees instead of truly valuing them.
Advice to Management
Get in touch with your people. As you grow bigger, the need for efficiency gets bigger too. But be surgical as you trim the "fat". Target the "cancer" so you don't kill off so many good cells. Don't promote people to management because of time served, but be critical that such persons have the management skills for the position. Empower your leaders - don't simply look for "yes-man" or someone who will simply tow the line. As fresh MBA graduates or experienced executives are recruited in, instill in them (and may be even yourself as well) the values of the founding fathers of this company so that their new, fresh, and even radical ideas (in how to increase profits) might be balanced with the values of both the patients and the people that makes this company great - it's employees.
Helpful (1

review_title: Great Work Being Done, Great Benefits, Stressful culture not knowing where next lay-offs were coming from
pros: Amgen does incredible work in researching and creating therapies for grievous illness. The staff are committed to what they do.
cons:
CEO is a Wall Street guy and that's how the company is now being run. The tag line is "Every patient every time" - but is it really? Terrific research was being done at their Washington State sites, with many potential molecules for the pipeline, but Amgen shut those sites down. Selling the Helix Campus for $240 million (40 acres ON the waterfront of Seattle - state of the art research labs, which cost $630 million to build in the first place). Why? To please Wall Street and Shareholders.
Advice to Management
Stop trying to please Wall Street and Shareholders and get back to the heart of what the company was founded for.

review_title: Good company, bad place for technologists
pros:
Overall, corporate culture is good. Lots of transparency and communication from management, clear focus on business of serving patients.

- Incredible 401k matching and company automatically contributes 5% for all employees
- Decent health care plans
- Subsidized meals at several cafeterias that serve excellent, healthy food
- Frequent employee focussed corporate events
cons:
The problems start for those of us who are career technologists. Amgen simply does not value this skill, and is intent on outsourcing every possible aspect of technology. This would be ok if they kept competent, motivated technologists on staff to manage / develop the processes and technologies used. 

Too frequently, the only management left are those folks that came from pure technology roles, but many years ago. The result is a technology organization that looks very much like it belongs in the late 1990s.

There are pockets of smaller groups where innovation and leveraging current technologies to achieve greater business value does happen, but the larger "IS" organization is not this way. The result is lots of fragmentation, no cohesive strategies to adopt new processes or technologies, and political in-fighting.

To top it off, the greater organizations management is focussed on self-preservation through outsourcing, and have not had the experience that many of us have had that shows how outsourcing requires more discipline and costs than promised.

The other aspect that is quite draining amount of time used by administrative tasks, unproductive meetings and so on. The organization is heavy with analysts and project managers that only know how to communicate via meetings.

Limited growth opportunities due to the above establishment.
Advice to Management
Even though technology is not your core competency, you must learn to treat technology and technologists as assets and not just costs that can be outsourced. Your competition is starting to do this, so it's only a matter of time before this will become a roadblock to your growth.

Please, please start offering the aging IS management early retirement and bring in fresh faces from leaner organizations. That's the only thing that will make Amgen "the best source for talent"
Helpful (2

employee_status: Senior Quality Analyst in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: Amgen has a very talented workforce that is committed to quality & safety. They offer part cutting edge technologies in their search for life saving therapies. You are constantly learning and growing at Amgen if you are able to stay plugged in.
cons:
Mentoring and teaching opportunities mentioned above, are not typically provided to contract employees in most departments. Unfortunately, the majority of Amgen staff is now made up of contract employees. The disconnect is becoming more and more evident.
Advice to Management
If contractors are here to stay there has to be a way to include them in the mentoring / training / development programs offered to full time staff especially when they are working side by side in the same roles or on the same teams. A lack of knowledge by any one person affects the group as a whole. It will also give contractors an incentive and / or buy-in per se to more fully participate in their role while on contract (often up to 18+ months).

Amgen is in the middle of a big transformational change program. CEO says we are "right where we need to be" to meet our financial commitments to investors. Lots of change has already happened--lots still to go.
cons:
Pretty isolated from the rest of the industry down in SoCal, which leads to some siloed and pretty antiquated approaches to things. 35-year-old company still feels adolescent for a company its size. Decision-making remains a struggle with everyone wanting to weigh in on everything and therefore very slow to get anything done.

You need to change even more than you think you do. Also need to create promotion opportunities for staff and not expect them to be happy with multiple laterals under the claim of "broadening one's experience."

cons:
Dysfunctional leadership in Operations struggle to make decisions. Rounds of layoffs have shed serious talent and concentrated an increasing workload on remaining staff - work/life balance is unachievable. Negligible diversity in senior leadership style - "strong leader" = aggressive autocrat. Morale incredibly low and people are stressed.
Advice to Management
Amgen needs to remember that its success has been due to its people, their families and the communities that supported them. Current management treats people, at least in Operations, as disposable. To instill loyalty and inspire a person's best work, you cannot continue to throw people away after you've squeezed them dry. Who would want to work for Amgen, when there are so many competitors willing to offer a more dignified and fulfilling workplace?

pros:
Generous benefits and time off, including summer and winter shutdowns.
Several recent marketing approvals with the potential for more via a robust and diverse development pipeline
"Healthy" stock price
Discretionary bonus usually paid every Spring.
cons:
The only way up...is out. Company will not create an Assoc Dir level so senior managers cannot advance. Many managers and senior managers have left to take director-level positions at other companies.
Sites in Bay Area and Cambridge expanding to support research, but not development; backfill for development positions is slow to non-existent at these sites.
CEO is a "numbers guy" and while the stock price is healthy, he has NO IDEA what it took to get it that way. He'd lose his mind if he had to work on a marketing submission.
Their plans for streamlining and finding efficiencies sound noble on paper, but that's just corporate-speak for "doing more with less."
Company can sometimes get in their own way with layers of governance and oversight that prolong activities.
Advice to Management
Give employees a career ladder to climb, not a jungle gym to dangle.
Give your middle managers the power of approval so teams don't have to wait weeks or months for an Exec/Steering Committee to do it.

review_title: Good compensation, great benefits poor corporate culture
pros: Great benefits, good salaries, a "prestige" name in biotech
cons:
Amgen is run like it was taken over by a hedge fund. No corporate culture left whatsoever. They call themselves a "science based company." The products are based on great scientific research but the rest of the company is noticeably lacking in the consideration of science or even intelligence. There is a noticeable dearth of smart people here. They love people with fancy MBA's from elite institutions but they like followers here, innovation is decidedly frowned upon. Sales and marketing have lost almost all connection to any real appreciation of scientific data.Not their fault, senior management has profit as the singular and exclusive goal.
Advice to Management
Get a soul. 3000 people got laid off in 2015 the same year that the company recorded record profits. The bottom line is the only line here and while that has helped many a shareholder make money, including me, it's not the right way to run a business in the long run.

review_title: Great company to work for while you're there, but no one is immune to RIFs
pros: Stock options, 401k, gym onsite, lots of other perks (talk to the veteran admins, they will know), paid week off week of July 4th, paid week off between Christmas and New Year, competitive pay, decent severance packages
cons:
No one is immune to lay-offs. If they decide they want to change direction and your group is no longer relevant to the direction they want to take it, your xx years of service won't mean much.

Also, there seem to be a lot of employees who feel entitled to more than they deserve.
Advice to Management
Be more transparent with your staff.

employee_status: Administrative Coordinator II in Thousand Oaks, CA
pros: All staff are pleasant to work with, except for the RAC (Regular Administrative Coordinator) employees. RAC are consider the permanent AC (Administrative Coordinator) employees, not the contractors (temp employees).
cons:
99% of the RAC's are very negative and miserable individuals to work with, definitely not a team player, and most definitely toxic to the Amgen company. Per the AC contractors, 99 % of the RAC's has the reputation of the MAFIA AC's. While the AC contractors are working to accomplish all tasks for the day, the RAC's are out playing doing the following.... personal calls, personal errands, yoga classes/gym/walking, visiting eachother, gossiping via email or phone (landline/cellular) to other RAC's about the AC contractors, complaining about their bosses (business/personal lives), their tasks, other colleagues and their colleague tasks, frequent visits to all of the campus restaurants, cafes, coffee stands, direspecting direct reports and scientists, etc. Once the RAC's realize all of the work the AC contractors are accomplishing not only for their boss, but also assisting other colleagues and other RAC's bosses /direct reports/colleagues due to the RAC out on leave (medical, vacation, sick, etc)... the RAC's starts feeling threaten. RAC's starts immediately spreading childish rumors such as the AC contractor are imcompetent of acheiving their tasks. The RAC's not only accomplish their childish rumors, cause friction between all Amgen employees and contractors, they also black ball the AC Contractor from their contract with Amgen and all subsidiaries. Due to this childish behavior it causes complications for the AC contractor to seek employment elsewhere. Contractors have informed their temp agencies about Amgen's work habits and disturbing behaviors.
Advice to Management
Monitor all RAC's work habits and behaviors, starting with Amgen President AC then proceed down the chain. Amgen is definitely not a team player or a family company as they try to portray. Amgen headquarters has a very poor reputation in Southern California with mistreating their contractors which is 80% of the company. Its time to clean house and replace the 99% of RAC's with the hard working contractors. Starting with the President since he is incompetent to see or hear with whats going on Amgen's headquarters campus. Once Amgen has cleaned house, the productivity will definitely rise because the moral of the employees (permanent and contractors) wil be up. This also pertains to some of the senior directors and their direct reports. Sometimes the title of the position goes to certain individuals head. These certain individuals thinks they have the right to mistreat their subordinates (direct reports/ scienctists) which contractors have observed many times. I am very fortunate I assisted a wonderful dept minus the surrounding RAC's, which I have received many compliants from many of my dept colleagues and other depts (Senior Director, Direct-Reports, Scientists, other contractors, temp agencies, etc.). 99% of the RAC's have the mentality they are not disposable because of their seniority with Amgen. If this was any other company, they would be out the front door due to their behavior. Good luck with cleaning house because the RAC's is one BIG click and they watch eachothers backs, this is why they are called the AC Mafia.
Helpful (3
